message: I am looking forward to today's start of the 115th Congress. It is a privilege to serve the people of the 12th District of Texas. #ConfidentAmerica

Thank you for your phone calls this morning expressing your thoughts about the proposed change to the Office of Congressional Ethics. I wanted you to know I voted against it. The change will not be included in today’s vote on the House Rules.

Today I was presented the U.S. Navy Distinguished Public Service Award. This award, established in 1951, is the highest recognition presented to civilians by the Secretary of the Navy for “specific courageous or heroic acts or exceptionally outstanding service of substantial and long-term benefit to the Navy, Marine Corps, or Department of the Navy as a whole.” I am humbled by this incredible honor. In my work in Congress, nothing is more important than national defense. It has been the honor of my lifetime to help fund and support the men and women in uniform and their families. It is me who is grateful for their outstanding service.

I recently personally purchased a carved longhorn skull to display in my D.C. office so that constituents can feel right at home when they visit. Many thanks to constituents from the 12th District, Cameron from Weatherford, Texas and Rylie from Fort Worth, Texas, whose artistic skills created this amazing piece right in Fort Worth.

The men and women who serve in law enforcement put their lives on the line to keep our communities safe and protect our families from crime. On this Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, and every day, we thank them.

I am honored to be asked to serve as Chairwoman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee. The challenges facing our nation are serious—terrorism remains a global threat and our military has been reduced during the Obama years.  To be safe, we must be strong.  I will work with my colleagues to rebuild America’s military.  Now is the time to invest in our military and ensure it is stronger than ever.

During a surprise naming ceremony in Weatherford, Texas earlier this week, the Parker County Jail was renamed the Sheriff Larry Fowler Law Enforcement Center. Sheriff Fowler has served as Sheriff of Parker County since 2005 and is rightfully one of the most well-respected citizens in the county.
"Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase." #MLKDay2017

I hear from constituents every day who have lost their health insurance plans and seen their costs go up. To read my most recent e-newsletter on this topic, please visit the link below. #ConfidentAmerica

My DC office was pleased to welcome a group of students from All Saints' Episcopal School and Hill School this morning. These bright students are in the nation's capital this week as part of their civic education experience. During their meeting, students talked and asked questions about the legislative process and being active citizens in our democracy.
Thank you Jon-David for having me on The Wells Report on 660 AM The Answer. In case you missed it, the link is below.

I want to congratulate the 45th President of the United States on his inauguration today in Washington. The peaceful passage of power from one president to another, from one party to another, is what makes our American experiment in democracy and self-government exceptional.
Click the link below to see my statement on the Obama Administration, in its final hours, defying a Congressional hold I placed on $221 million for the Palestinian territories.
I meant it when I said that the United States should seriously reexamine our financial support of the United Nations.

Isaiah Milligan Terrell became the head of the East 9th Street School in 1882. This school was the first free public school for African Americans in Fort Worth, Texas. Principal Terrell would eventually leave the school and continue to be an impressive advocate for education. In 1921, a new school building in Fort Worth was named in his honor. The historic I.M. Terrell building still stands today just east of downtown Fort Worth. Below is a picture of Principal Terrell and the faculty of the East 9th Street School for the 1889-1890 school year. #BlackHistoryMonth #12thDistrictHistory

Earlier this week, it was great to have a talented group of students from R.L. Paschal High School in Fort Worth, Texas come to visit the United States Capitol. I wish them the best of luck in their studies, and safe travels home.
"America's best days are yet to come. Our proudest moments are yet to be. Our most glorious achievements are just ahead."   President Ronald Reagan was born on this day in 1911.

New federal regulations must be carefully vetted to make sure they don't hurt jobs and job creators. To see what I'm doing in Congress to cut red tape and promote a healthy economy for all Americans, click on this week's e-newsletter.

Born in 1870, Bill Pickett became the best-known African American cowboy and entertained crowds at rodeos across the country - and the world. He invented bulldogging, which was a technique he used to grab a steer's head and get it to the ground. You may have seen the bronze statue below of Bill Pickett bulldogging in front of the Cowtown Coliseum. It was unveiled in 1987. #BlackHistoryMonth #12thDistrictHistory

As a reminder to any high school artists in the 12th District, the 2017 Congressional Art Competition deadline to submit artwork is 5:00 PM on Friday, February 24th. For more information, or to make an appointment to drop off artwork, please visit the below link.
NA

I was pleased to welcome the Chancellor, Vice Chancellor and other members of the Tarrant County College (TCC) administration to the United States Capitol this week. TCC serves over 50,000 students and is the seventh-largest college or university in Texas. I am grateful that they made time to see me while they were in Washington, and I appreciate them sharing their views on higher education legislation with me.

Congress is committed to providing immediate regulatory relief to small businesses and families. Under the Congressional Review Act, Congress has 60 legislative days to review and repeal as many harmful regulations as possible. To learn more, please click below.

This weekend I spoke at the Rotary Club of Fort Worth's first Hands on Peace Event (H.O.P.E.) at Texas Wesleyan University. The Conference brought together people in our community for a conversation on the Rotary organization's goals of preventing and mediating conflict. I shared some of my work as Mayor and in Congress to build a more peaceful city, country and world. After, I had the opportunity to answer questions from the audience about a wide-range of current issues before Congress. (Photo: Rodger Mallison)

The Congressional Art Competition gives student artists in the 12th District the opportunity to submit their work for the chance to have it displayed in the U.S. Capitol. I was pleased to meet the talented artists and see their work today. I also want to again thank the judges and Dr. Muñoz at Tarrant County College for hosting us this year.

I was proud to speak on the floor of the House in support of the Fiscal Year 2017 Defense Appropriations bill, which passed on a vote of 371-48. Our number one responsibility as Members of Congress is to provide for the defense of this nation. The passage of this bill ensures the United States will be strong and able to lead in this very dangerous world.

The number one concern of people in the 12th District is the future of the American healthcare system. This is a primary concern of mine, and why I wanted to give you more information on what is happening now in Washington.
Thank you Mayor Trevino and the North Richland Hills City Hall for coming to D.C. to discuss how issues at the federal level are impacting city government in the 12th District.
This week's e-newsletter discusses three pieces of legislation I am proud to support that take important steps to help veterans.

Proud to join Congresswoman Nita Lowey onstage at AIPAC Policy Conference this afternoon to talk about the importance of bipartisan support for the U.S.-Israel relationship and our work together to strengthen it.
On #VietnamVeteransDay we honor the service and sacrifice of those who answered the call to serve our country. We remember and appreciate you - today and every day. (photo: Brad Loper)
This week I chaired the first two hearings of the House Appropriations Defense Subcommittee in the 115th Congress.

Tonight, the White House made me aware that the United States would no longer stand idly by as President Assad slaughters his own people. I cannot more strongly applaud President Trump's decisive actions against the Government of Syria. For years we have watched as the Syrian people endured unimaginable atrocities at the hand of their own government. The world cannot allow this type of evil to go unchecked.  Tonight the United States has shown we are ready to lead the fight.
Wishing all who celebrate in the 12th District a Happy Passover.

I was pleased to help welcome U.S. Navy Commander Michel Falzone, the first female Commanding Officer of the USS Fort Worth (LCS 3), to my hometown of Fort Worth, Texas this week. We served together on the USS Fort Worth LCS-3 Support Committee's panel discussion about women in leadership with Mayor Price.
Wishing you and your family a Good Friday and a blessed and Happy Easter.

UPS employees in the 12th District dedicate their spare time to mentoring young children and helping them shape better futures. It was an honor to take part in a presentation today marking the generous support of the UPS Foundation to Big Brothers Big Sisters Lone Star. This is a great example of the spirit of volunteerism that is so common in our community and makes it strong. #ThankfulThursday

Thank you to the impressive junior and senior students at Young Women's Leadership Academy for welcoming me to campus this morning. I enjoyed meeting with you and congratulating you on your prestigious Blue Ribbon recognition.
In this week's e-newsletter I'm sharing some of my travels throughout our community during the district work period. To read it, please visit the link below.
NA
In this week's e-newsletter, I'm sharing some of my thoughts about the continuing resolution vote today. To read it, please visit the link below.
In this week's e-newsletter, I'm sharing some of my thoughts about the health care vote. To read it, please visit the link below.
NA
NA
So proud to introduce bipartisan and bicameral legislation today to help more children find homes through international adoption.
Thank you to all those serving in the military on this Armed Forces Day. We appreciate all you do in the service of our country.

Congresswoman Kay Granger (R-TX) today released the following statement on the White House budget proposal for Fiscal Year 2018:  “Our military leaders have all emphatically told me that they urgently need more personnel, funding for maintenance, modernization, training, and equipment. The President’s budget is a start,” Rep. Granger said. “As the defense appropriations chairwoman, it’s my job to make sure our leaders in uniform have the resources they need to protect the nation. To that end, we will look closely at the defense budget to make sure our priorities are where they should be. In my opinion, there is no higher duty than making sure our joint forces have what they need to keep America safe.”

Congratulations to the finalists in the “What’s Right About America” essay contest and to all the fifth-grade graduates being honored tonight at Kay Granger Elementary.   Have a wonderful summer and the best of luck in middle school. A special thanks to Principal Michelle McAdams for her commitment to the students of @grangerelem.            “What’s Right About America” essay contest                        First Place: Avery Bedichek                       Second Place: Annaliese Wentroble                       Third Place: Cruz Olguin                       Fourth Place: Jaeden McCarthy

So proud of the 35 young ladies graduating from the Young Women's Leadership Academy this month. The Class of 2017 is truly full of future leaders for Texas and our nation. It was an honor to attend your Senior Signing Day last week.

Each year I have the distinct honor of appointing young men and women to the military service academies. These men and women are among the best our country has to offer. These candidates will go on to be some of our nation’s finest military leaders. From left: William Pickell, Bryce Kleinman, Rep. Kay Granger, William Trawick, Andrew McNay.

Congratulations to the Eagle Mountain-Saginaw and Fort Worth Independent School Districts for being recognized as Best Communities for Music Education by the National Association of Music Merchants. #supportmusic

On this day we honor those men and women of our armed forces who made the ultimate sacrifice to defend our freedoms. Words cannot adequately describe the debt we owe them. Memorial Day is a time of remembrance, of appreciation, and of silent reflection on our own commitment to country and to each other. Thank you and God bless.
Today marks the 73rd anniversary of D-Day. Let us remember and honor the sacrifice of those from the Greatest Generation who helped liberate Europe.

Proud to vote in favor of passing the Iraq and Syria Genocide Emergency Relief and Accountability Act of 2017 to help Christians, Yazidis, and other religious and ethnic minorities targeted by ISIS. http://bit.ly/2rCaBGB

I want to thank Charles Anderson, John Johnson, Ret. Brig. Gen. Robin Akin and Ret. Maj. Gen. Kevin Pottinger of the Fort Worth Air Power Council for coming by my Capitol Hill office today and for everything they do to support Fort Worth's military personnel.

Listening to Adm. John Richardson this morning about the Navy's priorities for the coming fiscal year. I want to thank Adm. Richardson and his team for taking the time to discuss the Navy's needs as the service faces growing challenges around the globe.
Kudos to Fort Worth Police Department officers William Margolis and Christopher Weir and the employees of the Fort Worth Home Depot for going the extra mile to help a neighbor in need.

My prayers this morning are with my colleague, Rep. Scalise, and the other victims of this senseless and cowardly act of violence. I want to thank the Capitol Police who were at the park this morning for their quick response and selfless dedication. We are all Americans, and we must stand together against any attempt to divide us.

I want to thank Gen. David Goldfein, chief of staff for the Air Force, for meeting with me today to discuss the Air Force's efforts to improve combat readiness and increase force size under President Trump's budget proposal. The House Defense Appropriations panel will take up the defense budget tomorrow morning at 9 a.m.
Celebrating the U.S. Army's 242nd birthday today and thanking the men and women of our land force for their commitment to our nation.

Happy to welcome two dozen accounting students from Texas Christian University to Capitol Hill today and to the House Appropriations Committee hearing with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. #GoHornedFrogs
Today I joined my colleagues in the House in passing HR 2372, the VETERAN Act, to give veterans a choice between going to the VA for health care or choosing private insurance.

Since becoming chair of Defense Appropriations, I have said the defense bill would be based on the needs of the military and the best military advice from our leaders in uniform. Unfortunately, after extensive conversations with our military leaders, I am concerned that the FY18 defense budget request is not enough to address the shortfalls and damage caused by years of underfunding. The budget caps have exacerbated the problem and must be repealed.

Look who stopped by our Capitol Hill office this week. Students from V.R. Eaton High School in Haslet, Texas. The students are in town for the Junior Achievement National Student Leadership Summit. As participants in Junior Achievement of the Chisholm Trail, Inc. (Fort Worth), the Haslet students will present two small business start-ups they created at the J.A. Entrepreneurship Expo.

Proud to support passage tonight of two pieces of legislation to help children in need. H.R. 2742 will expedite the placement of foster children into safe homes. H.R. 2834 will help keep families together by strengthening the Regional Partnership Grant program, which provides funding to States to address child abuse and neglect related to substance abuse by parents. Both bills passed the House unanimously.

The House passed three more bills - five in total - tonight to strengthen families and make common-sense updates to our foster care system:  H.R.  2847 - Improving Services for Older Youth in Foster Care Act - Permits former foster youth to receive support until the age of 23, if they live in a state with extended foster care until the age of 21. The bill also allows them to receive educational vouchers up to the age of 26.  H.R. 2866 - Reducing Barriers for Relative Foster Parents Act – Requires the Department of Health and Human Services to create licensing standards for foster homes, and for states to notify HHS if their state standards are in line with the national model. The bill, which is aimed at allowing more relatives to become foster parents, also requires states to report to HHS if they waive non-safety standards for foster children placed with relatives, and explain their reasoning if they do not use the waiver.   H.R. 2857 - Supporting Families in Substance Abuse Treatment Act - Works to keep families together as parents seek treatment for addiction by allowing foster care payments for a child who is placed with a parent in a licensed residential family-based treatment facility.

Today I supported House passage of H.R. 2131 and H.R. 1282 to improve transparency and accountability at the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Together these bills will help ensure that money is being spent responsibly within the department and improve accountability.
NA
NA
Tonight the House passed HR 2547 and HR 2258 to expand employment opportunities for veterans by allowing their service experience to qualify for certain professional certifications.

The House just approved legislation sponsored by Rep. Paul Ryan reaffirming America's commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's principle of collective defense, supports the decision at the 2014 NATO summit that each member nation would spend at least 2 percent of its GDP on defense by 2024, condemns threats to any NATO ally, and welcomes Montenegro into the NATO alliance.
The House today passed a resolution condemning the violence and persecution in Chechnya.
NA

"Today’s decision from the Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw the WOTUS rule and restore some commonsense to our national regulatory system is good news for Texans. The rule as expanded under the previous administration was a dramatic example of federal overreach and would have had devastating effects on our state.”

At a hearing on Tuesday of the House Appropriations subcommittee on state and foreign operations, UN Ambassador Nikki Haley responds to my concerns about anti-Israeli UN resolution 2334 and the importance of diplomacy and American engagement around the world.

Congratulations to Milton Dempsey for being named a nominee for the John H. Chafee Environmental Excellence Award this year. Dempsey received the nomination for going above and beyond in his job to make sure Union Pacific's work at the Davidson Yard in Fort Worth is environmentally friendly. That's the Texas spirit.

Since becoming chair, I have made it my priority to listen first and foremost to our defense and intelligence experts so that we can ensure they have what they need to face both current and future threats. The bill before you reflects the advice we received from them. It provides Secretary Mattis with the resources he needs to implement his plan to restore our military.
Thank you to a great group of interns - Henri, Cole, Savannah, and Derrick. All your hard work these past weeks was greatly appreciated. Best of luck and always remember your Texas roots.
Check out my latest commentary on the need to repeal the 2011 Budget Control Act and provide the military with the funding necessary to keep our nation secure.

A big thank you to everyone at Presbyterian Night Shelter for giving my staff a tour of True Worth Place this past week. True Worth Place offers services to individuals experiencing homelessness in Fort Worth. Each day, True Worth Place welcomes nearly 325 men and women into a facility that offers day shelter, supportive services, resources and access to collaborating partner agencies. The work of the staff at the Presbyterian Night Shelter and True Worth Place is making a real difference in the lives of individuals caught in the struggle of homelessness.

Congratulations to Brock High School senior Austin Pitts, 12th District of Texas winner of the Congressional Art Competition. Austin and his teacher Sue Brunner are standing before his winning entry, “Union,” on display in the Capitol.

The June 30 Veterans Luncheon hosted by the Roll Call organization in Fort Worth recognized Mr. Cox, a World War II veteran, on his 100th birthday. The monthly Roll Call lunches are organized by Kevin Boldt, a retired Army medic. They honor veterans who served in World War II, Korea, Vietnam, both Gulf Wars, and Afghanistan.

This Fourth of July as you celebrate with friends and family take a moment to reflect on what it means to be American and the blessings we share as citizens of this great nation and the great state of Texas. Enjoy a happy and safe Fourth of July.

It was an honor to be photographed with the Combined Joint Task Force (CJTF) Troy's  American flag during the Fort Worth Fourth of July celebration. CJTF was the first operational counter-Improvised Explosive Device task force in U.S. military history. While the task force disbanded in 2011, their flag remains a constant reminder of their work training U.S. forces how to defeat IEDs thanks to its caretaker, LCDR Thomas Ames. Shown here with me and the CJTF American flag is Ames, Fort Worth Mayor Betsy Price, Rep. Marc Veasey, and J.D. Granger.

Friday's Star-Telegram editorial highlights my work on the defense appropriations bill.    "This defense appropriations bill for fiscal year 2018 tacks on a bigger cost up front, but provides key programs the appropriate funding to be functional. Instead of patching up old battle machines, this bill provides enough money to replace the machines, give machinists more training and prevent issues down the line."

Congratulations to Latricia Davis of Fort Worth for completing the Peace Teachers Program at the U.S. Institute of Peace. The professional development program trains middle and high school teachers to incorporate global peacebuilding themes and skills into their classrooms. So glad my staff could attend and watch Latricia make her final presentation today in D.C. Good luck back in Texas.

Kudos to all the volunteers who helped the Azle Lions Club put together Back-to-School Backpacks for their annual backpack drive. The Azle Lions Club donates a portion of the backpacks to local schools. The backpacks have everything elementary students need for the first day of school.

My office is now accepting applications for the U.S. Service Academies. This is a wonderful way to serve your country and earn your college degree. The application deadline is Oct. 13 this year. Make sure to get yours in on time.
John McCain is one of the toughest men I know. He’s never been one to shy away from a fight and I don’t expect him to do so this time. My thoughts and prayers are with John and his family.
Thank you to Marine Corps Barracks, Washington, D.C. and Lt. Gen. Steve Rudder for this great honor.

On Wednesday, I spoke in favor of language in the fiscal year 2018 State and Foreign Operations Appropriations bill prohibiting the State Department from spending funds to establish a new U.S. embassy in Cuba.  The language blocks the State Department from spending funds to open a new embassy in Cuba or to aid that country from opening an embassy in the United States.

A big thank you to the Friends of the Fort Worth Herd and the Friends of the Cowtown Coliseum for the wonderful tribute last night at the annual American Cowboy Gala at the historic Fort Worth Stockyards. It's always wonderful to be home.
The F-35 program is bringing jobs and economic growth to Fort Worth. Check out this great story by WFAA ABC 8 from earlier this week.

Lockheed's job fair in Fort Worth leads to 860 job offers. Great news for the economy. The job fair was so successful that Lockheed is planning a second one thanks in no small part to the company's development of the F-35 fighter jet.

I want to thank Chairman Diaz-Balart for taking time out of his busy schedule to visit Fort Worth on Friday. I always appreciate the opportunity to educate my colleagues about important projects in our district.
I want to thank Rep. Martha Roby for hosting me on a visit to the Alabama National Guard's 187 Fighter Wing and Maxwell-Gunter Air Force Base in Montgomery over the weekend.

Today, I am proud to support passage of H.R. 3218, the Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act. The bill expands educational benefits in the post-9/11 GI bill for service members, veterans, and their families. Veterans who served for less than 36 months would receive a larger percentage of benefits, and students at schools that permanently close would not lose benefit payments. Additionally, Reserve and National Guard members who are called to active duty would qualify for benefits, and Purple Heart recipients would qualify for full educational benefits. I am proud to support the service men and women and their families who sacrifice so much for our safety. #forevergibill

"The sanctions legislation we passed today in the House will increase economic and political pressure on Russia, the Islamic Republic of Iran, and North Korea. It sends a strong message to our adversaries that aggression against our interests will not be tolerated. I urge the Senate to take up and pass this important legislation quickly so that the president can sign it into law."

On the House floor now managing the defense appropriations bill. Our highest priority is the security of the American people. That’s why the House is voting today to fund critical national defense programs. Watch live: http://bit.ly/2vMCrzZ
NA

Our military leaders have testified that they urgently need more personnel, more funding for maintenance, more funding for modernization, more funding for training and equipment, this bill answers that call.

Yesterday, the House passed four of the 12 annual appropriations bills required to fund the government, including the defense appropriations. The defense bill increases funding for national defense by $21 billion and authorizes additional resources to counter threats, increase end-strength, and enhance our military’s readiness. Find out more about the bill below.
The House this morning passed an extension to the VA Choice and Quality Employment Act to ensure veterans can receive timely medical care in their own communities.

Speaking on the House floor last week on the importance of increased funding for the military in the FY18 Defense Appropriations bill, which was passed on Thursday. I wanted to thank the staff on the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee and my personal office for all their hard work to get this critical bill across the finish line.
NA

Today marks the 227th birthday of the U.S. Coast Guard, founded in 1790 by Alexander Hamilton. I want to express my appreciation to the brave men and women of the Coast Guard who risk their lives to save others in danger at sea, enforce our nation's treaties and laws, protect the marine environment, ensure a safe and efficient marine transportation system, and conduct national defense missions worldwide. Thank you for being "Semper Paratus - Always Ready" to meet our nation's 21st-century demands.

The Air Force today is honoring Capt. Jamie Lemieux of Decatur, Texas, for heroism during combat. Capt. Lemieux's decisive and deliberate actions over the skies of Iraq last November saved the lives of two American journalists and their Iraqi escorts who were pinned down and surrounded by ISIS fighters. Congratulations to a Texas hero for being a true Portrait in Courage.

Human trafficking isn’t something we think of as being a major problem in America, but the truth is that no part of the country is immune, including our corner of North Texas. My latest opinion piece in Sunday's Star-Telegram talks about what Congress is doing to end human trafficking with tougher penalties for sex traffickers and increased support for victims, and how local Fort Worth leaders are responding to the challenge and helping protect our most vulnerable.
Proud to see Fort Worth-based American Airlines has pledged to step up efforts to protect victims of human trafficking and child sexual exploitation.

I am thrilled to congratulate South Hills High graduate Romane Mays for being awarded a full college scholarship through the Texas Christian University Scholars program. Romane can be proud that his ongoing commitment to his academic studies is paying off. Romane's mother, Gina Casteal, also has a lot to be proud of. Gina overcame homelessness to earn a commercial drivers license through Goodwill’s North Texas Institute, which led to a job at Goodwill and the ability to provide a home for Romane and his three siblings.

Thank you to Parker County Today Magazine for selecting me as one of the Top 10 Most Interesting Parker County People You Should Meet Before You Die. It was a wonderful evening spent visiting and catching up with the people of Parker County.

"The recent events in Charlottesville are abhorrent and are not representative of the core values and morals of the United States. As a nation, we can have a civil debate over the differences in our beliefs, but we must condemn white supremacist groups like the KKK and neo-Nazis that promote bigotry, antisemitism, racism, and violence. Freedom and liberty are the foundations of this country, and therefore it is incumbent upon us as Americans to take a stand against such despicable acts of hatred." - Congresswoman Kay Granger, Co-Chair of the bipartisan Anti-Semitism Caucus in the U.S. House of Representatives.
Thank you, Sheldon Metz for coming into the Fort Worth office to discuss the current healthcare debate and educate my staff about the work of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

Last week I met with a group of local agents from the New York Life Insurance Company to talk about congressional efforts to reform the federal tax code to make it more simple, affordable and competitive.

I wholeheartedly support the President’s decision to follow Defense Secretary James Mattis’ recommendation to increase troop levels in Afghanistan. This modest increase will allow us to provide better support to the Afghan security forces and ensure we continue to have a strong ally in the fight against terrorism. In addition, it is important that Pakistan is working with us to deny terrorists a safe haven. http://bit.ly/2vZHMUU

I had a good conversation Monday evening in Decatur with constituents from across the district about health care, national security, and education. Check out the Wise County Messenger's coverage of the meeting.

Every year, mayors from around my district gather at the Mayors' Roundtable to discuss issues that they are facing in their communities. This event encourages cooperation between neighboring cities and provides a platform for us to share information and coordinate plans to address common issues. As the representative for Texas 12th U.S. Congressional District, I appreciate hearing from our communities' elected leaders on how I can best support them.

As Hurricane Harvey prepares to make landfall, here are some tips to keep everyone safe:   Google has hurricane alerts in Google Search that will provide an estimate of the storm’s arrival to your location and its projected impact. Just type in your location in Google Search for localized information.   If the storm is expected to affect your area, know your evacuation zone and follow the direction of state, local or tribal officials if an evacuation is ordered for your area.   Visit fema.gov or Hurricanes.gov for updates on Hurricane Harvey. While you are there download the FEMA mobile app (available in English and Spanish), which provides a customizable checklist of emergency supplies, directions to open shelters and recovery centers, disaster survival tips, and weather alerts from the National Weather Service.  Visit www.ready.gov/hurricanes to learn more about preparing for hurricanes and severe weather.  The American Red Cross also has a list of available shelter locations in the path of the hurricane: http://rdcrss.org/2xjnC8H   You can also find a list of safety apps to help you weather the storm. Check them out here: http://rdcrss.org/2xjvB5O

Congratulations to Avery who won First Place in the "What’s Right About America” essay contest at Kay Granger Elementary! To commemorate her excellent work, a flag was flown for her over the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. Avery is a very smart young lady and I have no doubt that she will go on to do great things.
NA

There are no words to adequately convey our thanks and appreciation for all that the Texas National Guard and the entire National Guard do to protect and save Americans at home when disasters occur. The National Guard is always there when we need them. Check out this video of our Texas National Guard personnel hard at work helping their fellow Texans:

Download the FEMA Mobile App to receive alerts from the National Weather Service, get safety and survival tips, customize your emergency checklist, find your local shelter, and upload your disaster photos to help first responders.

To all of our friends and fellow Texans affected by Hurricane Harvey, please know that our thoughts and prayers remain with you during the trying time.   In the days ahead, please take note of these helpful resources published by the FCC.
NA
NA

16 years ago today, American history was forever changed. Today we remember the innocent people who were killed as well as the brave first responders and members of our military who continue to sacrifice to keep their fellow Americans safe.
NA

Tonight, millions of Jewish families around the country and the world will gather with family and friends at sunset in observance of the Jewish New Year, Rosh Hashanah. It’s a time to feast with friends and family as well as go to the synagogue and reflect on the past year, both pain and joy, and to pray for renewal and the year ahead. To all my friends in the Jewish community, I send my warmest wishes for a sweeter year to come.

Thank you to the fine people at the Texas Farm Bureau for taking the time to meet with me this evening to discuss important agricultural issues.  Farmers and ranchers are the backbone of this nation and they are among the most hard working Americans I know.

This morning I had a wonderful discussion with the Parker County Ministerial Alliance on how we can work together on challenges we face in our communities, and how to best overcome some of the discord that exists in our nation.   As Americans, it is critical that we speak out against the ills of society and stand up for what is right and just.
NA

The attack and murders in Las Vegas last night were horrific. I am thankful to our first responders who acted so quickly and prevented additional casualties. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families, the people of Las Vegas and all of those affected by this tragedy.
NA

On International Day of the Girl, I’m reminded of what Malala Yousafzai, who earned a Nobel Peace Prize for her advocacy of education for young women, said: “Let us make our future now, and let us make our dreams tomorrow's reality.” I had the privilege of meeting Malala two years ago. She is one of the strongest individuals whom I have ever had the honor of meeting. Her story has been an inspiration to me, and I hope her example will galvanize others to advance rights and opportunities for girls everywhere.

After a late night meeting with leaders of the U.S. House of Representatives, and consulting with Governor Abbott, members of the Texas delegation have identified nearly $15 billion of emergency funding for Texas to be included in the emergency disaster funding bill expected to be voted on later today in the House.  In a telephone call with members of the Texas Delegation, Governor Abbott expressed his commitment to continuing to work with the Texas Congressional Delegation and Congressional Leadership to ensure that Texas has the resources needed to recover and rebuild.  The measure includes $11 billion to pay anticipated claims for flood insurance for Texans who are victims of Hurricane Harvey, and an estimated $4 billion for the FEMA disaster relief fund for Texas. The new FEMA funding for Texas will provide direct housing assistance, home repairs, debris removal and public assistance grants to eligible communities to begin repairs of roads, utility work, schools and public buildings.  The flood insurance program is expected to run out of money within weeks – meaning Texas claims would not be paid – and FEMA funding will be exhausted soon due to the faster than expected drawdown to address Hurricane Maria claims.  In addition to the $15 billion, Texas cities will also have access to a $4.9 billion pool for grants for Community Disaster Loans.  These loans help communities with revenue losses due to disasters, so the communities can pay for police and fire protection and other critical local needs during their recovery.  “Our top priority is to make sure money doesn’t run out in the next few weeks for Texas homeowners eager to rebuild their homes, as well as communities counting on FEMA funding for temporary housing, debris removal and infrastructure repairs for roads and schools,” said Representatives John Culberson of Houston, John Carter of Round Rock, and Kay Granger of Fort Worth, chairmen of key Appropriations Committee panels in Congress. “These emergency needs require action right now or a lot of Texans will be hurt. We are keeping our eyes focused on the long term recovery needs for Texas, which could exceed $100 billion and we will continue to work closely with Governor Abbott and our community leaders to secure that funding in the weeks ahead.”  https://kaygranger.house.gov/press-release/texas-delegation-secures-15-billion-disaster-funds-emergency-funding-bill

Without a doubt, the so-called Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action was a bad agreement, and I am pleased that President Trump is taking action to reevaluate this dangerous deal. It has given Iran the green light on their nuclear program, as well as billions of dollars to prop up their crippled economy and fund terrorist organizations. As I said at the time, President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran jeopardized the safety and security of Americans and our allies throughout the world. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the House to do everything possible to ensure that Iran never has the ability to use nuclear weapons against the U.S., Israel or our allies.

On this Thanksgiving, I want to take a moment to express my gratitude for our great nation and those who serve. We have so much to be thankful for in this country. This Thanksgiving, I hope you will also remember those who have fought for the freedoms and opportunities our country is blessed with – especially those who are separated from their loved ones. On behalf of my family, I wish you and your family a safe and happy Thanksgiving.

Today, the bipartisan Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017 (H.R. 38) and the Fix NICS Act passed the U.S. House of Representatives.   The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017 ensures that law-abiding citizens’ Second Amendment rights do not end when they cross state lines. This legislation, which I was proud to cosponsor, allows residents with a state-issued concealed carry license or permit to travel freely between states without worrying about conflicting concealed carry reciprocity laws or onerous civil suits.   I was also pleased to support the bipartisan Fix NICS Act which passed the House today. Following the horrific acts of violence in Sutherland Springs, Texas we must do all we can to prevent these tragedies from happening again. This legislation would require federal and state authorities to enforce existing law and accurately report relevant criminal history records to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS). Had our existing background check laws been enforced, the tragedy in Sutherland Springs could have been avoided all together.
Never forget the brave men and women who lost their lives 76 years ago today #PearlHarbor

Yesterday, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a bill to protect Americans’ Second Amendment rights and to curb gun violence: the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act. This legislation is one of the most important pro-Second Amendment measures to have passed the House in recent memory.  The pro-gun bill that passed the House, which I was proud to cosponsor, would allow law-abiding citizens to carry concealed only if they are not federally prohibited from possessing or receiving a firearm. Citizens must also carry a valid government-issued photo ID, and be lawfully licensed or otherwise entitled to carry a concealed handgun. Each person would have to follow the laws of the state, county and municipality in which they are carrying concealed.  An overwhelming majority of Americans support concealed carry reciprocity – 73 percent of adults, according to a recent New York Times survey. It’s also backed by the attorneys general of 24 states, including Texas’ Attorney General, Ken Paxton.  Currently, the patchwork of reciprocity laws and agreements between states is confusing and has caused law-abiding citizens to unwittingly break the law and suffer arrest and detention. Even the most careful and knowledgeable concealed carry permit holders find it difficult to navigate the current maze of state and local concealed carry laws.  The Supreme Court ruled in 2008 that “the inherent right of self-defense has been central to the Second Amendment right,” which is “the individual right to possess and carry weapons in case of confrontation.” This fundamental right does not stop at a state’s borders and law-abiding citizens should be able to exercise this right when crossing state lines.  Contrary to what some critics say, if the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act becomes law states would retain their authority to enact time and place restrictions on where people can lawfully carry in the state. In addition, the bill would not make it any easier to buy a gun. It has nothing to do with the purchase of guns. It would not alter access to guns and it would not change the federal law requiring background checks.  This legislation will help protect Texans’ Second Amendment rights, and I was pleased to support it.
On this day in 1791, Congress ratified the Bill of Rights

Please join me in thanking Major Schenck for his service, and in wishing him well in his new endeavor.  https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/2017/12/11/extensions-of-remarks-section/article/e1678-2?r=281

Today, the House passed the most sweeping, pro-growth tax reform since President Reagan. These tax cuts will ensure Texans keep more of their hard earned money.  In addition, this legislation not only protects current American jobs but also encourages companies who have moved overseas to come home and bring jobs back to Texas.     The bill nearly doubles the standard tax deduction and reduces loopholes, while preserving important tax breaks such as the teacher tax deduction for classroom expenses. With this bill, the typical family of four earning the median family income of $73,000 will receive a tax cut of $2,059. The bill also expands the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $2,000 for single filers and married couples to help parents with the cost of raising children. It also allows Texans to write off up to $10,000 of their property taxes.  This legislation delivers real relief to businesses by lowering the corporate tax rate to 21 percent, down from 35 percent. In fact, it reduces taxes on small businesses to the lowest they’ve been in 40 years. Businesses will be able to immediately write off the full cost of new equipment to improve operations and enhance the skills of their workers.  There has been a lot of mischaracterization of what this bill does, but the American people will know the truth when they start to see more money in their paychecks as early as February of next year.  Congress has finally delivered on the promise of tax reform, and I am proud to have supported this historic tax bill.”

I was honored to receive the Great American Patriot Award yesterday at the Armed Forces Bowl. As your Congresswoman and as Chairwoman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee, I always fight to ensure that our military has what it needs to fight for and protect this great nation.
